## Regression design 
$$
g({W_{i|age=32}}) = \alpha_0 + \alpha_1 hs_{i|age=32} + \alpha_2 hs^{sd}_{i|age \in [21..30]} +
\bm{\beta X_{i}} + \epsilon_{i}
$$
$$
g({W_{i|age=42}}) = \alpha_0 + \alpha_1 hs_{i|age=42} + \alpha_2 hs^{sd}_{i|age \in [31..40]} +
\bm{\beta X_{i}} + \epsilon_{i}
$$
$$
... \text{ and so on } ...
$$

- $g()$ is the cubic root here, but other transformations available (asinh, neglog, 5th root, etc)
- $hs$ stands for _health score_. For simplicity only one is displayed, but both components are included in actual regression.
- $W$ is currently Net Wealth, but gross wealth results in around 30% high $R^2$.
- time subscript no longer present since one observation per individual.
- Linear regression with bootstrap standard errors

t-statitstic in parenthesis. 

Interpretation: 

- $mcs/pcs$: a one tenth of std. dev. increase in health score is associated with $x$ units increase in cubic root of net wealth
- $mcs^{sd}$/$pcs^{sd}$: a one unit increase in the standard deviation of the health score is associated with $x$ 
units increase in cubic root of net wealth



## Coefficient Graph 

\centering![](../../output/figures/coefplot/fig_coefplot_01.pdf){width=80%}

\raggedleft\scriptsize Note: 90\%, 95\% and 99\% conf. int. depecited as color shades and line thickness.

## Main points 

- Health scores in levels are positive and their variances are negative, indicating that:
    - higher health scores are correlated with higher wealth build-up years later, and 
    - higher health variability (specially meatal) are negatively correlated with later wealth build-up
- The variances are more often stat. significant. than their corresponding scores in levels
